textDisplay:
You can become a billionaire if you provide value worth a billion and capture the same amount of value back.

For example, by selling a product which has $50 of profit margin to 20 million people.

Yes you'll need money to make money, and in this day and age it's easy to get funding though through VCs/Angel Investors/Banks.

The question is, do you have the skills to market & produce such a product that can make 1 billion in profit or even sales? If you don't then obviously you won't become a billionaire.

Jeff Bezos was able to, as well as Bill Gates, Ratan Tata, Mukesh Ambani, etc.

Most aren't born into wealth. Around 60%-80% of millionaires are self made. 1 in 10 Americans are millionaires. It's easy to discredit millionaires & billionaires skills and hard work to make yourself feel better, especially if you have basic literacy, a roof over your head, food, and basic expenses being met.

There's still many problems worth solving, many of which can be worth billions, especially more so in poor countries like global warming (Elon Musk, Adani), human lifespan (Peter Thiel), mass scale advertising with low marginal costs (Mark Zuckerberg, Larry Page, Sergey Brin),etc. etc.

textDisplay: Some elements of your video lack basic logic, although overall I would agree with the basic sentiment. Looking at the pizza shop example, it's a gimmick, it wouldn't work long term because you haven't accounted for the cost of anything: flour, ingredients, electricity, water, etc. It was a PR stunt at best, because it's not sustainable. I do believe in paying people higher wages but it doesn't work in the small to medium enterprise realm because the profit margins are thin. A pizza shop doesn't make that much profit compared to a pizza franchise. Which is why I believe in heavily taxing corporations, not because they are under taxed, but because they are over powered when it comes to competing with locally owned businesses. A local pizza shop owner would rather shut down their operation over pay employees higher wages because what's the point of owning it if you're not going to keep a worth while profit.
textOriginal: Some elements of your video lack basic logic, although overall I would agree with the basic sentiment. Looking at the pizza shop example, it's a gimmick, it wouldn't work long term because you haven't accounted for the cost of anything: flour, ingredients, electricity, water, etc. It was a PR stunt at best, because it's not sustainable. I do believe in paying people higher wages but it doesn't work in the small to medium enterprise realm because the profit margins are thin. A pizza shop doesn't make that much profit compared to a pizza franchise. Which is why I believe in heavily taxing corporations, not because they are under taxed, but because they are over powered when it comes to competing with locally owned businesses. A local pizza shop owner would rather shut down their operation over pay employees higher wages because what's the point of owning it if you're not going to keep a worth while profit.

textDisplay:
This is catering to hate towards wealth. It's ok to hate others who are rich for some reason, whilst still craving wealth or villainizing it.

Your video implies that an employee should get all the cash value he or she brings to a business, when a business has overhead and risk-taking stakeholders who venture into it with the risk of losing it all and more. Businesses don't automatically succeed, far from it.

It also implies that a business needs to hire employees for the benefit of the employees, rather than to fulfil an actual job role. So it should take on risks in order to hire people solely for their benefit and not the business? You do realise that if that were how things worked, one sufficiently bad thing going wrong for the business will tank both the business and the employee's job stability, right? You are making the assumption that an employee is forced to work for tyrannical companies, and not that they have voluntarily signed a contract for employment. The more demand there is for specific skills, the more control over their income they may have, which is the opposite of the reductionist idea a hypothetical "company" asking people whether they want to eat or not is how the job market works. Another assumption is the idea that a business has unlimited money, which is simply not realistic. If they did, then sure, pay people more and just make money itself worth nothing too.

Naturally this sort of market leads to lowering costs, which does result in abhorrent practices on the extreme ends. Strictly speaking, unethical means doesn't mean a self-made billionare isn't still self-made, it's a different dimension of problems relating to how they became self-made, not whether or not they are. Building a business is about an organization of people, which is probably the only way to reach billionaire status other than inheriting from others who have done it.

Taking family wealth and privilege and turning it into billions is no small feat that anyone can do. If every child from a middle/upper middle class family were given 300,000 to start a billion dollar business.

The ideas you express sound "good" and on the surface will spread. But they are far too reductionist, wrong, and can cause dangerous outcomes. That is pretty unethical.

textDisplay:
Yeah. Knew this was bullshit when you said musk's dad owned an emerald mine "in apartheid south Africa." First, the mine wasn't even in south Africa. It was in independent Zambia. Second, it was half-ownership. Third, idk about you, but I don't know of too many lavish aristocrats who hock their stones in street shops, as both Elon and his father have said they did. Fourth, Elon left south Africa, and his father, in the early 90s, moving to Canada to avoid conscription in the SA military, and arrived with barely anything.

I find it interesting that this video closes out with you pushing unfounded assertions about "if we just didn't have billionaires, everything would be so much more fair. Your life would be so much better." Often those with no facts have to rely on demagoguery to push their agenda.

textDisplay: Most people want to believe the dream for obvious reasons. I wish companies had to reveal how they make their money not only to investors but to the nation so (potential) workers and buyers could make informed decisions. Fair political representation is also necessary since the rules have to be just. Question: Truly living by the Golden Rule: An "impossible utopia" or just good practice and simple common sense? Answer: It's the latter if you have any heart and soul. This is not a dog eat dog world unless people in power/gaining power choose to make it that way. If wealth, political power and military are all united by the same agenda you either have a bit of heaven or hell on earth. Extra Credit Question: Is heaven such a difficult choice? Answer: No - unless you're a narcissistic sociopath!

textDisplay:
Why would an entrepreneur want to pay tax to a govt that will lose that money in the layers of bureaucracy when he/she can directly help the people by hiring them? You see, at some point, the govt just becomes a sort of mafia. Did you ever wonder why those tax breaks were given? Maybe the company incurred a loss the previous year. Maybe the jobs created in the city by the company would help the population more and an added tax on the company would just add to their problems of actually making a difference.

If it was not for this capitalist system, no company or researcher would be incentivised to make those vaccines. It is the incentive that pushed companies like Pfizer and Moderna to save millions of lives. Just think about the absolute mind-boggling feat that these companies achieved by making a drug to save the world within a year! And they got compensated for it! Great! Good for them!

You'd still be sitting there unvaccinated with your loved ones, all living in fear of the ever-worsening pandemic if we were in a socialist system.

textDisplay:
I get that the message of socialism needs to be spread in America. It would be nice if people actually knew what it entails instead of using it as pejorative.

I’m living in Europe. In the US, everything is binary. So it’s either capitalism OR socialism; third options are excluded. In Europe, we have a hundred in-between options. In South-East Asia it’s even crazier: opposites can be combined. Yes, you can create social capitalism: corporations and the government working together to dramatically increase life standards for the common people. Some East-Asian countries have jumped from the third world to the first in merely two or three generations.

So my question is not whether capitalism or socialism is good or bad, my question is how to combine the good parts of both into something that works.

If you advocate socialism, you need to address the elephant in the room: it has been tried for the last hundred years in various countries and in general, more people have fled from socialist countries to capitalist countries than vice versa. I know people who visited Eastern Europe when it was still communistic. The reports vary from ‘it’s even worse than I thought’ to ‘I imagined it to be worse but I wouldn’t go to live there’.

True, there have been some successes in socialism. The Russians have reliable rocket technology and sure, Cuban doctors are top of the bill. Nevertheless, I don’t see masses of people from all over the world migrating to Cuba. Why is that?

I’m not saying that socialism sucks. As a member of a labour (social-democratic) party, my thinking is closer to socialism than to the liberal right. But even the ‘watered down’ version of socialism is a hard sell. I don’t think that this is due to a lack of understanding of people. People in Europe – the East both as the West – have a lot of experience with it and mostly have a fairly good idea of what they can expect.

So what is wrong with this picture? Quoting Marx is fine, but I don’t think you can apply a 19th century theory to the 21st century on a one to one basis. We need to understand why the practice is different from the theory. We need to understand what is needed to make socialism 2.0 or even 3.0. We need an improved version! But we can only do that if we thoroughly understand what went wrong with previous versions and how to correct the flaws.

Added to that, I really don’t think that capitalism is the enemy. In my country, we’ve had capitalism for more than four centuries. There have been bad episodes, but the overall effect is positive. Like socialism has good and bad parts, the same can be said about capitalism. Yes, you can cherry pick shining examples of socialist progression and you can highlight some of the vileness of capitalist extremes. But that’s clearly an incomplete argument.

What we need is a way to measure and compare both systems in terms that are not intrinsic to each. Otherwise you end up with socialism being the right thing according to socialist theory and capitalism being the right thing according to capitalist theory.
How can we make an unbiased comparison? How can we add the best of both together in a way that will be continued after the next contra-revolution because people still think this is the best way?

textDisplay: The concept of surplus value is pure nonsense. You have absolutely no way to account for the contribution of the owner, capitalist and entrepreneur in various decisions they make: to save, when to save, to invest and when to invst, to what, to decide to start a company, to organiz epeople, to observe the business and make sure that CEO leads it to profit, etc... - All those decisions are within very unique context of a given time, opportunities, places, changing ndustries, putting together unique teams of people, networking, building net of contracts, building trust etc. None of that can be taken account for in marxist analysis, because it is not repeatable like comodity production. Marxist analysis cannot take account for that exactly in the same way like in the case of art and performance.

textDisplay:
The big problem is that most people don’t know how to handle money. If everyone invested, lived below their means, and planned their lives we would have far more millionaires.

Of course most ultra wealthy inherited money their wealth, it has had longer to compound. However it’s extremely difficult to keep wealth in a family for more than a few generations due to divorce, rising number of heirs, mismanagement, and taxes. Look at the rockafellars for an example.

Socialism and communism produced the worst atrocities of the 20th century and many in the 21st. They are responsible for the Holocaust, 10million died in Russia, 100million died in China, North Korea starves its people to keep them subservient, Cubans live on government allotted rations.

Here in America many places have a $15dollar minimum wage, if you make 32k a yr you are the top 1% income earner in the world, 15*40*52=31,200. So basically our minimum standard of living crushes the average. Also heart disease and diabetes are the number one killers of the homeless here. In America even our homeless eat so good the are dying of abundance related issues.

Compare that to Venezuela where they went from one of the richest countries in the America’s to having the highest rate of child starvation. The socialist government did fix that problem though, they made it illegal for doctors to mark starvation as a cause of death, now the mark heart failure or renal malfunction.

Help each other up and don’t tear anyone down. I support a flat tax rate with no write offs.

textDisplay:
Why haven't Marxist systems seen any success?

Billionaires being exploitative (they are) does not make Marx quotable.

The owner of a company using surplus value to keep the company running is not always theft either. There are expenses to cover, such as maintenance, growth, loss of employees, hiring of new employees, bookkeeping, marketing, the list goes on....
I think this video comes from a place of mild, but dangerous, bitterness.

The claim that no billionaire has made it there by ethical means is also a bit questionable. If your ethics include paying the gross value of labor to your workforce all the time and considering management a non-skill or a valueless skill, then it truly is impossible to become wealthy ethically.

I don't think there is an ethical? way to take away wealth from individual billionaires.
The best we could do is persuade them to donate their money to improve society...

I do think incorporated businesses should be held more financially accountable to their workers, customers and the communities they operate in

I advocate for workers being shareholders.
Or for a worker coop. Sort of like a union but the workers with a particular skill form a corporation of their own
Like an electrician's coop would negotiate with corporations
Or even more apt, a driver coop. where united commercial drivers would negotiate with corporations as contractors.

textDisplay: So the pizza place example is a little misleading. The math is correct but if you read the article closely you'll notice what the boss actually did was pay his employees 100% of all sales they made. Cool. But that means on that day he didn't pay any bills for the store, no property or income tax, didn't pay for ingredients, didn't pay for advertising. Unfortunately, the $78 an hour wage would be impossible to sustain long term. That's not to say employees don't deserve a bigger cut of the total, but as an example for surplus value it's misleading. That money wasn't surplus at all.
textOriginal: So the pizza place example is a little misleading. textDisplay:
For the pizza example, if the shop owner never reaps any profits, what is the point of taking the initial risk to start a business? It requires capital, lots of planning and execution, and savvy to run a successful business - even a small pizza shop.
Now let's say the business fails, what do we do then? We can not bail them out as that would be just helping a failing business continue operating unsuccessfully.

Also, for Jeff Bezos to turn a $300k loan into what Amazon has become today is an insane business feat. Consider also all the lives it positively impacts and innovation that has came from it. It's not all one sided.

This video was terrible.
textOriginal:
For the pizza example, if the shop owner never reaps any profits, what is the point of taking the initial risk to start a business? It requires capital, lots of planning and execution, and savvy to run a successful business - even a small pizza shop. 
Now let's say the business fails, what do we do then? We can not bail them out as that would be just helping a failing business continue operating unsuccessfully. 

Also, for Jeff Bezos to turn a $300k loan into what Amazon has become today is an insane business feat. Consider also all the lives it positively impacts and innovation that has came from it. It's not all one sided. 

This video was terrible.

textDisplay:
If there were a hypothetical limit on how wealthy one could be, say $10,000,000 - then what would a financially motivated individual do once they hit this number? I'm guessing they'd probably leave the productive world and live off that wealth for a few generations.

But what if Bezos did that? What if he had a successful online bookstore that he sold back in 1998 and just kicked back in Palm Beach for the rest of his life? How about Musk, what if he just made a little boutique EV car shop that only sold local electric cars?

Maybe we would have ended up with 1000 Musks across the world, each with boutique shops. However maybe we'd disincentivize people from doing things that we ultimately benefit from, like clicking a button and having goods delivered to our door, tomorrow.

I found the Pizza store example particularly egregious - to get paid $78 an hour to make pizzas, yet there is no worry about advertising, the rent of the pizza store, the supplies, what happens when someone quits and what happens if, I don't know, say have to close down for months on end. Health inspectors, local taxes, etc. It is incredibly deceptive to show this example without touching on the counter argument in any way.

You receive a downvote sir. I would love to see someone like @MoneyMacro tear this video apart.

textDisplay:
7:41 I looked into the Pizza shop this dumbfuck disingenuously claimed could pay its employees $78 an hour if the owner stopped "siphoning off" money from their labour.

Not surprising to find that it was an employee appreciation day where the owner took the hit by giving the entire SALES+tips of the day to his employees. Not profit, sales. As in he took the hit on paying for all the expenses and liabilities (ie paying for the cost of good production, equipment or payments on the property) that would normally be deducted from those sales before they become the paper thin margins of profit restaurants operate under.

So unless you think expenses dont exist, this place, and the vast majority of restaurants could not in fact afford to pay their employees $78 an hour or anywhere close to that. Maybe learn like the high school basics of econ before you spout nonsense. Not a great look.

textDisplay: That pizza example is disingenuous.  You can't just divide gross daily sales by the number of people working that day and say that is their value to the restaurant.  There is food cost, other costs, rent, and all other overhead.  There's insurance, liability and all sorts of risks as well.  If that restaurant paid every worker $78 an hour, it wouldn't last a week before running out of money and going out of business.  It was a nice gesture to give all the workers a share of the daily gross sales (maybe a $500 bonus or so), but in reality even the owner probably barely makes $78 an hour if he's also the manager.  The average McDonald's franchise "owner" earns about $150k a year, which is equivalent to about $75 an hour for 40 hours a week for 50 weeks a year...
textOriginal: That pizza example is disingenuous.  You can't just divide gross daily sales by the number of people working that day and say that is their value to the restaurant.  There is food cost, other costs, rent, and all other overhead.  There's insurance, liability and all sorts of risks as well.  If that restaurant paid every worker $78 an hour, it wouldn't last a week before running out of money and going out of business. textDisplay: Make your own job. Its hard to start something and even harder to keep it afloat. Dont like making minimum? sacrifice all your extra money , time, and effort. Create your own wealth, easier said than done. Been at it for 10 months, with my own skills and risks, I am still walking a thin line between profitability and complete loss. Maybe in two years I will generate enough revenue to pay myself whatever I want. When that time comes should new employees demand higher than minimum wage for entry level jobs? Why should I pay them what I pay the people who stuck with me thru the tough times of development? Ive been a minimum wage worker, it sucks not having enough for what I WANT. But at the end of the day I legally must be paid. As a business owner, I pay myself last, I have had 6 months were I could not afford to pay myself. I still worked at a nursing home for $15 an hour so I can pay for things needed at my business. I am a high school drop out, if I can make it in a few more years, you can too.

I like your ideas about socialism and how it would work. It sounds great. I really do want to believe that. I understand that people say capitalism exploits people.
But this is the problem: its not CAPITALISM that exploits, it's the PEOPLE who exploit people and always have, for the last 6000 years. We change systems, but don't change people.
I come from a communist/socialist country - which failed like most all of them. Yes, we have few European countries which are more centrist capitalist, but they are the exception, rather than a rule.

Again, maybe I am wrong, but the motivation for any creation is the ownership. Take that away and the incentive dissapears.
I'm here at 9:22pm learning more so I can improve my investments, if I didn't get to keep the profits, I'd be out drinking.

textDisplay:
Very true facts about how billionaires get rich.

The question is ; "what are the options?".

Never in the history of mankind has a system existed without a group of people at the top who impulse innovation and job creation. Even in "socialist" states, the politicians end up richer and more oppressive than billionaires in "capitalist" states.

It is a fact that humans are not equal in traits. Some people are more innovative than others, some people are more hardworking than others, some people are more industrious than others,some people are better at execution than others,etc. To think people will all create jobs for themselves is a utopia. Society should create incentives for the more industrious to create jobs, for the more innovative to invent,etc and the way to do it is through a free market economy. On the other hand, people (including the billionaires and politicians) need to be checked so they don't become oppressive...that's the role of democratic institutions.

textDisplay: Regarding the pizza chain that shared money: how much of that did the employees set aside for insurance (unemployment, health, and business)? How much did they hold back for a new oven, for having to repave the parking lot, for the days when business sucked instead of boomed? That is how this balances out. The owner has to pay for all that maintenance that nobody else wants to do, and they have to do it even if they aren't currently making profits. Thus, they are rewarded for taking a disproportionate amount of risk that the average employee would never be asked to take on.

textDisplay:
This is so poorly researched and ill thought through. Yes there can be corrections in compensation and profit distribution but that surplus that your employer takes is for the infrastructure they provide for you to produce goods of value. A pizza shop worker doesn't pay rent for a commercial property he works on. He doesn't pay the oven, tools and utility costs. That same employer themselves would probably need a loan from investors or relatives or the bank. If the lenders aren't family why would they risk their money unless you guaranteed to pay back with good interests/profits. If they are family well then 1. they won't be able to lend as much money as institutional lenders/investors 2. The money they made was well deserved since even by your logic laborer's deserve their paycheck. Unless the family has a direct link to royalty or slave trade its just people's money accumulating bit by bit. Since there's an Inheritance tax then society has already taken its share if the wealth is multigenerational. If it's not then well its self made within a generation. Why would you hold that against someone? I'm all for raising low inheritance tax rates however we shouldn't go to the point we hurt the incentives for people who are motivated to produce goods so that they may benefit their children. No incentive = no production = no goods to tax = no wealth distributed.

Once again your employers get that surplus because its they who have to recover the capital sunk into the business. It's their compensation for seeing exactly how to put land workers and machines together in a way that will produce goods and services that people will want to buy. A pizzashop kitchen worker does not produce the entire pipeline by themselves. However after some experience, if they feel they are ready to seek out their own investors and open their own shop, then they will be entitled to that surplus if they make it profitable. However 90% of new businesses fail. So that just shows how difficult it is to make a business and why is the reward so high

textDisplay:
Elon turned $20,000 in to $382 million dollar company and he profited 22million from the sale, his personal earnings was a 110000% return on the invested capital, the company returned 1910000%. He did make that wealth, he did not steal it and he was not given it, hence it was created. So, yes he obviously is a self made billionaire and I must add, do you think that if you were given money from your family that you will magical become stupendously wealthy, this is the dumbest idea ever. This is obviously not true there are 20 million millionaires in the U.S, hell even a person with a house has a few thousand dollars in their home's equity why do they not just take $20,000 and multiply it by 110000% like Elon did. As if merely having access to wealth automatically means you can just keep creating more, most business ventures fail and even the ones that do work out result in average returns. And no I do not think it is a coincidence that Elon has a rich family, if you are smart than you are more valuable and tend to be able to create more wealth, mean while that smart person gets married and has a child... oh my gosh that child is also smart that is crazy how lucky!!... No, obviously intelligence is genetic.

So, yes his father was rich and one would speculate that Elon would turn out similarly, but how rich? yes, maybe a millionaire or maybe just a person earning a high 6 figure salary, or who know hes perhaps ends up just living off the money his farther made and squandering the wealth. No, instead he left home at 17 went to Canada and had essentially no contact with his farther (he had a failing out with his father to the point where even to this day he will not let his children see their grandfather) since, he was a young teen and when he was 25 dropped out of his PHD research and ask his farther if he would invest in their ( co found it with his cousin) business.

Now, it does not matter where he got the money from, because $20,000 is in investing terms scarps of scarps of scarps, do you have any idea how much capital it takes to make even a tiny business. Here, is just one example of something that is probably familiar; to open one McDonald it cost not $20,000, but anywhere from $1,008,000 to $2,214080, just to open it. Elon could have gotten the money from literately any investor at the time and that is not an over exaggeration, investors in silicon valley were funding the dumbest ventures ever companies that were entirely based on their domain name and had no actual value at all.

And last point, No and I mean no business owner says they made all their money from only their own work. Because every business needs to expand at some point and that requires capital and that means either getting loans, bonds or selling equity. So, yes you take other peoples money to create immensely valuable custom infrastructure that makes each business able to do what they do. I mean honestly list a signal billionaire who owns all the stock in their company, Elon only owns 20% of Tesla, Jeff only owns 10% so, clearly none of them did it just by themselves, no man does. Respond if you want, I will be able to explain the entire world financial system to you, This is what I study. While you describe business in cliche slogan that no actual entrepreneur of this century uses.

textDisplay:
I work for a subsidiary of Koch Industries. Because its a Koch subsidiary, we get free copies of Charles Koch's books containing his propaganda. One of his books is called "Good Profit". Normally I don't read such garbage, however I read the first couple chapters of the book.
What I read was quite amusing. It was full of hatred toward the government as a obstacle against their growth, how legal actions against them by the government wasn't their fault at all and that it was a technicality, excuses that they never want to get tax breaks from the government, but they use them anyways because "other people do" and they need to stay competitive.
One of the more funnier aspects of the book was how Koch described his early life and his father. He basically admitted that his father got into the oil industry because a friend of his fathers called him from a oil company he worked at about a potential merger with a bigger one and that he should invest money into the smaller one. A few days later, the merger finished and Koch's father gained millions.
The humor is that Charles Koch basically admitted his father committed insider trading.

textDisplay:
Thats the problem with the definition that is commonly used for the term "self made". The way it has been defined is that the wealth has not been acquired through inheritance, but rather through your own entrepreneurial venture. The problem is that it allows people like Kylie Jenner (who was born into a family of millionaires) to be classified as "self-made" even though she had access to all the wealth, notoriety and connections that came with being part of the most famous family in the world.
It just doesnt account for the all the advantages and financial support that these people got that plenty just dont have access to

textDisplay:
Overwhelmingly I agree most billionares are not self-made and exploitation is a large factor. But, you mention the "absurd $4.9 billion in loans and tax breaks" but you do not mention how SpaceX has saved NASA >$10 billion by offering cheaper access to space. Seems like a one sided argument?
I am sure Musk, Bezos and other billionares have factors of exploitation and tax breaks, but saying its just free money they got but not describing the benefits they offered is very one sided. Bezos took advantage of his early move and now we have free next day shipping. If you think they've exploited the world so much, why do you use their services and continue to reward them?
The capitalist system gives massive advantage to the early mover who does a good job at managing and expanding. The issue is the early mover owns most of the company for whatever it becomes, hence their wealth goes up. The "tax" is based on income, so the rich dont pay themselves. There are obvious loop holes in the system like no wealth tax, or estate tax which would seriously hamper wealth growth.
Overall dislike on the video for being too one sided.
Honest feedback.

textDisplay:
I do want to point out about the Ohio pizza article, the owner gave all money coming in to the employees, not just profits. Which the video fails to mention, meaning that the pizza company would not be able to pay these crazy salaries and still stay in business. It does not take into effect the rent/mortgage, the utilities, and other overhead costs, plus the food costs themselves to buy the products to sell.

So while it sounds like the owner is making $78 per hour and only paying $9-15 per hour is simply not the case as this video wants you to believe. It would probably be after expenses of food and all overhead costs around $20-25 an hour per employee before their wages, so the owner is probably making $5-10 per hour over the actual costs per employee, which I think is fair for the owner who risks everything.

So I think what he did was a good thing for his employees to show appreciation, I think people are taking it out of context and acting as if the owner could probably pay his employees $30-$50 an hour and still make a profit on top of it, which is just not the case. The maker of the video twisted the original story.
textOriginal:
I do want to point out about the Ohio pizza article, the owner gave all money coming in to the employees, not just profits. Which the video fails to mention, meaning that the pizza company would not be able to pay these crazy salaries and still stay in business. It does not take into effect the rent/mortgage, the utilities, and other overhead costs, plus the food costs themselves to buy the products to sell. 

So while it sounds like the owner is making $78 per hour and only paying $9-15 per hour is simply not the case as this video wants you to believe. It would probably be after expenses of food and all overhead costs around $20-25 an hour per employee before their wages, so the owner is probably making $5-10 per hour over the actual costs per employee, which I think is fair for the owner who risks everything.

So I think what he did was a good thing for his employees to show appreciation, I think people are taking it out of context and acting as if the owner could probably pay his employees $30-$50 an hour and still make a profit on top of it, which is just not the case. textDisplay:
I really don't understand how people keep falling for "Trickledown". This myth has been used to give the tax dollars of ordinary workers to the fat-cats for decades now since Reagan and Thatcher set capital free.

We have seen an obscene growth in the wealth at the top, yet we still have a minimum wage that is not a living wage, a society run on credit, people on the streets and unable to afford medical care. no trickledown there.

We all know which way money travels and it is neither a trickle nor is it going down.

Put money in at the bottom, spend on the poor and that money will inevitably travel upwards and benefit every level of society.

textDisplay: Sounds great, but if what this video says is true, why doesn’t everyone just start their own businesses and quit working for their bosses? If I put in more time, energy, sweat and tear than the guy I hire, who only works from 9 to 5 Monday through Friday, while I work from 5 to 9 seven days a week, why should he get paid the same as me???  Explain that.  And that’s even before we consider that it’s always the business owner that puts in the initial capital, which means if the business fails, he/she is totally fucked; do employees have to take that level of risk?  NO, THEY DON’T!

It is stupid to think that the levels of responsibility and risk are the same for the owners than the workers, and thus there needs to be an incentive (compensation) for the system to exist.
That said, the problem probably runs because of the hoarding nature of wealth. If that wealth was spent - other people could benefit from that spending.

textDisplay:
I'd just like to point out: Saying Elon Musk's father gave him anything is absolute BS. Yes, he did give some money, but Elon's father never had been really well liked by anyone, including Elon. In fact, Elon gives more credit for his success to his mother than his father- Why? Because his mother didnt give him anything, just raised him right.

Which is, similar to my situation: oh yeah, my father could give me money, but we don't really like each other. This is a very simple way to explain Elon's relationship with his father; Its a love-hate relationship. Elon generally dislikes him, but appreciates his minimal help when Elon was failling and going bankrupt.

Having studied Elon's life, and read every single book from everywhere on the political spectrum about him, i can confidently say: Relative to other billionaires, Elon definetely isnt who should be targeted. My question is: why Target individuals with massive ammounts of money, when the US government spends nearly 700 billion on the Military?

That 700 million (which is actual money, and not tied up in stocks or investments like most billionaires' money.) could be invested elsewhere: Imagine a NASA with a 65 billion $ budget, an education system with 100 billion $, Medicare and maybe even Pharmacare.. All of those things, and much more, would easily be achievable if the US cut their defense budget, by, say, 65-75% which, considering the current political situation, is reasonable. So instead of tackling people who's NET WORTH (and not back account) is worth 200 billion, why not attack the US' absurd expenses in absurd fields?

textDisplay: The pizza article says in the excerpts ON YOUR VIDEO that all revenue was given to workers that day, not just profits. You are saying all profit should go to workers, which I can (mostly) get behind, but that is not what the pizza shop example shows. The owner made a loss of the amount of the other resources other than labor in that example. The workers received the profit + the money that would have recomped the business for dough, other ingredients, electricity used, rent for that time, etc. Which means the owner of that business made an active LOSS of all those expenses for that day. ALL businesses would go out of business if you instituted that going forward. I like your videos but bad faith arguments like these are starting to make me distrust them.

textDisplay: How does a $300k investment mean someone isn't self made? Bezos' parents didn't build the business for him. Large initial investments and strong support from institutional investors is NECESSARY to build a successful business. You can say that they were lucky to have parents that could offer that support, but you don't have to be rich to loan 300k, most people can achieve a financial state where, if they start saving at 25 and grow their money, they could afford to invest $300k in their sons business 20-30 years down the line without being super rich. Not saying bezos parents aren't rich just making a point. Financial literacy is one of the biggest reasons videos like this are so successful, you talk about how the billionaires try to sell us a reality but never acknowledge the fact that you're trying to sell us a reality too, you mean to convince us that hard work doesn't pay off and entrepreneurs don't have it easy unless they come from rich parents or a privileged background. You mean to persuade your audience that even if they posses the skills, they shouldn't try to start a business because it's a false dream and will be impossible without support. You intend to make these people believe that they're NOT capable of becoming successful, whether you call that millionaire, billionaire, or wealthy, thats what this video's point is - to crucify the rich and justify it by saying how impossible it is for others to gain success. I've always noticed this bias to your videos, and it's really dishonest the way you frame them. We can hold the rich accountable without taking motivation away from people with a dream, an idea, and the courage to pursue it.

textDisplay:
The modest gift my late parents left me allowed me to purchase a small place and be able to pay it off in 3 years. I'm on payment 18 out of 36. With only HOA fees I will be able to save 40% of my net income for retirement.
Without this gift my apartment which was $700 in 2013 I'd be paying $1,400 a month today. If I were lucky enough to get property A mortgage would take me 30 years to pay off.

Regardless of the amount gifted, the domino effect of an injection of money well spent can change a person's financial future. My late parents did more for me in 3 years than I've been able to do financially in 30!! And in no way can I say my current or future financial Outlook is all due to my hard work.

textDisplay:
I got an ad during this video about how to make 6 figures a year. 😂

You really gotta think about wealth inequality. People will say that if you made that money, you should be able to do what you want with it. Why should you have to give your money away? My brother said that he got taxed so much for making more money that he might as well just not work as much.
Well, it's not really giving it away when that money helps better society, whether it be actually paying your workers enough to live comfortably, or paying your taxes so social services can work properly. If these billionaires did that, they'd still be filthy rich, but the people below them and society as a whole would be much better off as a result.

I have the belief that if I came into money through work or luck, I would share that money with the people who deserve it or the people who are close to me. Whenever I say this, people doubt me and say that I would change once I get that money. They don't understand that I grew up with very little. The things I have I've earned, while also giving to my friends and family. I don't want a fancy car, I drive a used 2008 Civic Hybrid. I don't want a big house, I dream of living in a little bungalow. What would I need with such riches? If I had a surplus of money then I would give to others, it's that easy. When I make more money, I give more money. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Billionaires have undue influence on democratically-elected leaders which means that the democracy in the so-called "democratic" countries is nothing more than a false facade. The existence of billionaires is what I call "The rise of the modern aristocracy".

When you're a country that worships money and wealth, it's no wonder that Billionaires are considered celebrities instead of the sick bastards that they are, twisted by greed. I'm absolutely sickened by this idea that Billionaires are somehow heroes. If I ran the world, people would be forced to retire once they had $5,000,000 in assets. At that point, they don't need the job they have anymore while someone else DOES need it. A policy like that would mean prosperity for the WHOLE country, not just the top 1%. The fact that billionaires can exist while other people starve is proof that the capitalistic system has outlived its usefulness.

textDisplay: 7:41 As you can see in the text on the screen, that restaurant owner didn't just give their workers the surplus value (profit), they also gave them all the money that came into the shop, in which some of that would normally go back to the restaurant for expenses (buying the food, the equipment, etc). textDisplay:
Good video, nice facts. But there are several points you have made I think are right and wrong. The biggest wrong is that current US economy is capitalist but corporatist economy.
Right:
1. There are no self-made billionaires. It's close to impossible to start from nothing to the top. Your family wealth, country you were born in and etc. all are factors.
2. Without government support and tax breaks it would be impossible to those companies to get revenues. And for this there need to be some kind of contract that will tax them in the future because their investment come from taxpayers.
Wrong:
1. Current US and in general world's self proclaimed capitalist economies are not even close to capitalism, it's corporatism where few wealthy companies lobby politicians which in turn make laws in favour of their big businesses but set unfavourable conditions for small businesses and middle classes. Real capitalism will only be possible when small unelected groups don't have power over money and today that's possible through cryptocurrencies like bitcoin, ethereum and etc. You can see capitalists' true "capitalist" face when they express their hate to true capitalist money.
2. Although mentioned priviliges also play important role on becoming billionaires their personal skills also play roles. It's hard to accept but humans have different skill levels. Even given the same oppurtunities some people will climb to the top while others not.

textDisplay:
I'm a bleeding heart leftist, but the explanation at 7:13 is just a gross simplification, and is just counter productive. While a lot of employers blatantly underpay their workers that it can count as "stealing", "stealing" is not an inherent part of the system.

The value produced by company should be more than the sum of the value produced by the individual workers. They're working together and combining their efforts BECAUSE of the company.

Accusing a company making profit is inherently stealing from the employees is like saying your body is stealing from it's individual organs because the body as a whole produces a surplus of nutrients so it can manage to grow bigger. No. No matter how good an individual organ is (e.g. a heart), its worth as a solitary organ is WAY smaller (in this case zero) when its not part of a larger, complex, organized, and well-managed system.

Yes, it's stealing when employers underpay their employees. But the system can be improved to stop that from happening. Government regulations, unions, investigative journalism, progressive taxation, etc., they're part of the solution. Just branding it as stealing means you're just gonna do away with the solutions and create/join a new system altogether. Let's hope that system isn't Communism...

Obviously, there is overhead to running a shop, but from the sounds of things, the Pizza Place could likely double the wages of all their employees on the regular, or set up a fluctuating bonus system depending on weekly or monthly total earnings, and still cover that overhead while packing some away for company profit.

I work at a store where we're expected to sell credit cards. You know what we get for selling enough cards? If we sell a certain amount in a day, we get some snacks at the end of the week.

The fucking banks (who are just dumping the extra work on the cashiers) are raking in the interest, while the people actually getting customers signed up get dick, and then wonder why threatening us with write-ups isn't enough motivation to make the cashiers bully the customers into going into further debt.

You want to incentivize credit cards sales? PAY US CASH MONEY FOR EVERY CARD WE MANAGE TO SELL. You know what motivates me to make YOU money more than maybe getting a bag of M&Ms on Friday? BEING ABLE TO PAY MY FUCKING ELECTRIC BILL. Jesus, this fucking country.

textDisplay: I worked at a pizza hut once. On a Friday, from lunch to closing, we would of had 4 servers, 1 manager, 4 cooks and 1 dish washer (average, with a staff of 3 between lunch and dinner down times). The manager told me about the deposit for that evening shift once. An average night was about 6,000 dollars. 10 of us working 8 hours was 80 hours. 80 hours into $6000 = $75 an hour so I think that Pizza Restaurant statistic was pretty accurate. This was in 1990. All of us could of made $40 an hour and the owner still would of been making a healthy profit, while we did all the work. I am not against capitalism and I think most businesses should be privately owned, but I think we need to require higher wages, especially, when so much profit is being generated by the people doing the actual work.

textDisplay: I often wonder if folks like you second-guess the whimsical way in which you toss out generalities of this ilk to prop up your points, or if you actually think said tactics are necessary. Then I reflect on the articulate, deliberate, prideful stance taken and the relativistic research you leverage in your leanings and can’t help but giggle until I gag. You led with Rhi-Rhi’s rise as the stuff you revile, yet your whole rant focused on Besos building an empire on 10% of what Trump lit on fire and an unfounded anger towards Musk based on his family history in spite of his history - making it ever-so-obvious that you clearly couldn’t tie that to his empire. And sure, I appreciate the obvious as much as the next nerd, but if you can’t manage to monetize a channel with 1.1 million subs, you may want to consider what you’re doing wrong instead of indicating that those who succeed in your stead only do so because of generational wealth. There’s more to it than that and we both know it, and shame on you for emphasizing such a simplistic view of the haves and have nots. You are definition of basic, kid, and consider this your call-out. I will happily debate you in an open forum at the drop of a hat, despite the fact that we agree on a number of points related to proper taxation and the sad-sack state of employee compensation. But we both know you’re positively petrified at the prospect of such things, so feel free to cower in your corner while imploring your audience for empowerment - the same thing you just claimed was the only way anyone gets ahead. You’re a clown.

Then I reflect on the articulate, deliberate, prideful stance taken and the relativistic research you leverage in your leanings and can’t help but giggle until I gag. You led with Rhi-Rhi’s rise as the stuff you revile, yet your whole rant focused on Besos building an empire on 10% of what Trump lit on fire and an unfounded anger towards Musk based on his family history in spite of his history - making it ever-so-obvious that you clearly couldn’t tie that to his empire. And sure, I appreciate the obvious as much as the next nerd, but if you can’t manage to monetize a channel with 1.1 million subs, you may want to consider what you’re doing wrong instead of indicating that those who succeed in your stead only do so because of generational wealth. There’s more to it than that and we both know it, and shame on you for emphasizing such a simplistic view of the haves and have nots. You are definition of basic, kid, and consider this your call-out. I will happily debate you in an open forum at the drop of a hat, despite the fact that we agree on a number of points related to proper taxation and the sad-sack state of employee compensation. But we both know you’re positively petrified at the prospect of such things, so feel free to cower in your corner while imploring your audience for empowerment - the same thing you just claimed was the only way anyone gets ahead. You’re a clown.

textDisplay: @7:49 I do not think this event means what you think it means. The owner gave the workers all the money coming into the store, not just profits. If a business does that all the time, then how will it ever stay open? Are the employees then going to use their wages to pay the rent, bills, upgrades and maintenance of equipment, etc that are needed to keep the business running? The surplus value is reflected in the profit - if the owner had just given their employees all of the profit then that would be making your point. What they actually did is in no way financially sustainable, socialist or not.
textOriginal: @7:49 I do not think this event means what you think it means.  The owner gave the workers *all* the money coming into the store, not just profits.  If a business does that all the time, then how will it ever stay open?  Are the employees then going to use their wages to pay the rent, bills, upgrades and maintenance of equipment, etc that are needed to keep the business running?  The surplus value is reflected in the profit - if the owner had just given their employees all of the *profit* then that would be making your point.  What they actually did is in no way financially sustainable, socialist or not.

textDisplay: Hey, I mostly agree, that the top of the top should pay more in taxes (at very least because there is literally nothing they can't buy already, even few generations ahead), but some of your arguments are just incorrect. Namely, the pizza store example. In the text you're presenting it's explicitly stated that all the income, not just profits, went to the salary. That's just not viable in the day-to-day operations, where you have to pay for electricity, rent, flour and toppings. Also, it was apparently kind of an advertisement, so the store might've had more people than usual that day. Using such examples is what enables criticism of the idea. So, if it was stated if those were money divided from the actual profits - that's intense. In reality, it's more likely to be 2-5 times more, which is still enough to make the case, but won't allow for pretty obvious criticism of your logic. Please, continue your work though, I like it a lot

textDisplay: Man, I don't get why so many people find the argument that labor/profit is exploitation so convincing. textDisplay:
oh i already know this video is gonna piss me off.


1) no, nobody in earnest makes the claim that "aNyOnE cAn bE a BiLliOnAiRe" it takes a special kind of person and mind to be able to compete in the high-stakes world of the high-value market. if you have any sort of mental disability, illness, or shorthand, you are set to fail from the start. in addition; you have to be excellent at persuasion, and charismatic enough to convince other people that you are correct without offending them. you cant get upset or discouraged when an idea of yours fails, and you have to be willing to spend hundreds of hours, sacrifice your every personal relationship, in order to make the money necessary, so that you can afford the correct decisions, to make more money. this snowball effect of the perfect storm creates a billionaire, and sorry, only 00.2% of the population has ever made it work. does this mean that the 00.2% didnt in fact earn their money? a huge portion of the population is homeless, most of them due to mental illness, divorce, or serious health complication that has taken everything they had. most of them have no family, no friends, and no future. does this mean that you, a middle-class blue collar worker working in an office job didnt earn your money? after all, most people wouldnt be able to do your job, shouldnt you be taxed higher, or shouldnt you be forced to give your money away to those who "need it more"???

sure, not every billionaire who ever existed started from the bottom, but that doesnt mean they dont exist. most people starting from the bottom suffer a lot of mental health and social compromise just in order to survive, but listen-

just a year ago, i lived with my dad in a trailer that had a collapsed roof and floor- we had 400 dollars a month to pay our electric, provide food for our 3 cats and a dog, and support gas money and licenses. if we didnt get a deer or a hog during general gun season through hunting, we where gonna starve. we couldnt afford good health insurance, and we wore clothes that where 10 years old at least. we where in poverty. Now, we live in a 400000 dollar home, im getting a Culinary Arts degree through college, we own a boat for fishing, and we have ample money for food, clothing, and good hygiene. if i play my cards right today, i could continue to snowball off this success, and eventually... i might become a billionaire. i might not have what it takes, but i wont know until i try. should i not be allowed to keep the money i have earned? should i not, if i become a billionaire a few years down the line, be allowed to keep the money i earned? have i not earned what i bled, sweat, and nearly died for?

2) honestly? fuck you, im 2 minutes in and im already fed up with your privileged, snide, callous little weasel-ass. i want you to wake up tomorrow and drink 20 gallons of Dawn Dish soap, before crawling in an industrial washing machine while it's still running. you make me sick.

Excuse my ignorance but wouldn’t everyone having more money just mean prices would go up and inflation would go out of control to meet the new money that is in circulation through redistribution?

By my calculations if all the US$ was evenly distributed everyone would have about 44k each. That won’t save most people and it would pretty much all be spent in a couple months.

Maybe there isn’t a problem with ultra wealthy there is a problem with too much debt creation if we weren’t able to take out debt so easily then we wouldn’t have this “fake” inflation caused by debt bubbles which force the lower middle class and bellow to make themselves in to debt slaves just to afford the basics. If less money(debt) was in circulation or if debt was really backed by real money the cost of goods would go down and we’d be able to afford basic things without all our money being stolen by interest and taxes.

textDisplay:
This video is talking about some of the bad things, yet fails to mention any good things. This stuff is way too hard to analyze for a 10 min video.

So let's say someone gave Bezos a 300k capital to launch his business - fine. How many people in the world had 300k at that time? You can easily answer this question - a lot. However, how many of those people decided to change the retail industry and start a fully online only business & succeeded at the same time... oh well, oh well. You said that Musk had parents that made a good living, fine. Does this have anything to do with him being successful with fully electric car factory built from scratch? Would you like to analyze how many car manufacturers tried to start either from scratch or revive an established brand and failed... the answer is that almost 100% of new car companies fail and it's extremely difficult to build a new business - also this has 0 to do with taxes. However, if you want to talk taxes, how about talking how much money the NASA has spent on new rockets without ever building one? Your "government" used billions of dollars for decades and had 0 results, whereas Musk created cheap & re-usable rockets within 10 years and is now making NASA spend less tax money.

Also none of these guys are capitalists & all of them have different views on business. You can also mention someone like Bill Gates whose parents were insanely rich and who had access to computer when most people only saw it in science fiction movies. His mother was on the board of the first company to which he sold his software and made money. Go think.

Most of the issues are created by the government in the first place. How about all of these laws and loopholes - where did they come from? How about inefficient spending - where did that come from? How about corrupt politicians & millions of people that live without decent salary of healthcare - ask your representatives.

textDisplay:
First off I’d like to start this comment by stating I am not necessarily a supporter of conservative, libertarian or capitalist ideologies. It need to be said that this video claims that if wealth was redistributed then everyone would have enough.

What marxists fail to recognize is that there would be no river of wealth to distribute from if there was no Amazon. The pizzeria referenced in this video would not exist to pay the workers any wage at all.

What Marxism does is politicize the economy. Wealth is never redistributed fairly to the workers but is always redistributed to the ruling class.

American works still have it better than any worker in the Soviet Union, China, and North Korea ever did.

Don’t listen to communist/Marxist and capitalist propaganda. They are both out dated and disaster out modes of thinking. Both sides have the general population trapped in the belief that their choices are limited to left/right.

What we need is not a new economic system but a new social contract based on mutual respect, human rights, and personal freedom. Not more government control or exploitative aristocracy.

textDisplay:
Great video but the pizza parlor example was so stupid it made my head hurt. Those 78$ weren't profits, they were the whole revenue. Profit is revenue minus all expenses (salaries, rent, insurance, investments...) believe me, for most restaurants almost nothing is left after you pay all those expenses. That's why most restaurants go bancrupt pretty fast, it's a tough business. Now if the minimum wage were higher, restaurants could charge more and not lose customers because all the other restaurants will charge more as well. But just giving higher wages is really hard and risky.
We could talk about the fact that rent it too damn high, which is a huge reason many businesses get strangled. That's a way people get richer just by being rich and sitting on their asses while wage earners and small businesses struggle to survive.

textDisplay: This video like most of the nonsense out there is absolutely ridiculous, if you are going to support Marxism at least make half way intelligent arguments to do so for in this video it states some truth to start with ‘such as the fact that most billionaires are not truly self made & when it comes down to it no man or woman is an island & therefore nobody is truly self made’ but then it spins off to try to convince an extremist agenda in about the most ridiculous & poorly thought out presentation I’ve ever seen. Absurdly in an absolute black & white blanket statement that ‘no billionaire achieves wealth honesty is a joke’ & through I would be the first to admit there is other content out there that often spins the opposing extremist agenda ‘making it sound as if big business is honest & trust worthy with only hard working honest people becoming wealthy & government incentives & regulation to give big business an unfair advantage is for the greater good’ is also ridiculous, the truth is that those videos like this one do not consider the grey & intricacy of the real world, the world is filled with lies & many of those lies come from the billionaires but most come from extremist fools that speak about things they barely have the intelligence to understand not alone rationally discuss, any fool who claims that people do not obtain wealth unless they are corrupt or received unfair handouts is a fool who has never studied history or really analyzed anything with any depth whatsoever. textDisplay: This analisys in a little problematic, as a worker you cannot expect to profit from the total value of your work, that's unrealistic as any company would go bankrupt if they did consistently, but on the other hand the explotation it does exist when companies pay their workers wages that doesn't allow a person to substain themselves or their families and the work they do is not reflected on their salaries... Those two are some extremes that the upper class and Marxists people try to impose.. but there's a whole range in the middle where workers get paid a fair quantity for their labor, adequate to their capabilities and the value they bring to their company, it's really misleading to talk about billioners that way and offer an equally extreme point of view as a solution, without the promise of great profit no one would dare to make any financial risk, and that's something that cannot be overlooked ..

textDisplay:
I fundamentally disagree with this video.
I can agree that there are Billionaires who are made with the help of family privilege, however I don’t see that as a bad thing.
I would much rather my kid use my inheritance to him properly and growing it rather than just spending it and wasting it.

The vast majority of millionaires on the other hand are in fact “self made” whatever that means. I like to believe that I’m self made, but by your logic I’m not. So let’s look into what that means for a second…
I would disagree that Jeff Bezos isn’t a self made billionaire despite his $300k loan from his parents.
Turning $300k into a $1 billion is like turning $300 into $1 million, which is extremely difficult… Imagine turning $300k into $1.7 Trillion

I say Trillion because it’s important to keep in mind that Amazon has a total market capitalisation of about $1.7 Trillion.
While some may think that this is bad, the proper way to view it is that Jeff has created about $1.5 Trillion in wealth for other people. Aka shareholders, which anyone can be regardless of gender, height, net-worth, skin colour, religion etc.

Jeff fully deserves his wealth, so does Elon and I do not expect them to give it away with socialism.

If you implement socialism, I can promise you that Jeff will be long gone from America. (Unless he’s advocating for it, in which case be extremely weary). So will Elon, so will I, so will anyone who understands how an economy functions.

The Ohio pizza shop did not give the employees the surplus value, the owner gave them ALL the money, not just the profits. He didn't account for the value of rent for the day, utilities, or anything else.
The average pizza worker makes 27k in the US, average pizza restaurant owner makes 60k on average per year.
A pizza place usually has like 5 employees, so they'd take 12k each if the owner made 0 money whatsoever. They wouldn't be making $78 an hour In that case either.

textDisplay:
You know what you're right.

Even though the government subsidy might have less uncertainty and grow the 'economy' but the benefit actually lies in the upper echelon of the 'economy'. I never thought of it in that way.

For example lets say we have a low savings rate for some community and the government wants to incentives people to save for old age they can either spend money on education and invest money in the community and lets say the net return on investment is 3%. After a while a bank analyses the situation and brings a 'solution' where if they receive the money from the investment as a subsidy they can increase the net return on investment to 5% but for that to happen they use the money to build a gated community or a golf course estate and attract more wealthy individuals to the community and then increase the average savings rate because they added more biased people instead of helping the community.

Thus fulfilling their obligation and making more wealth by building the estate and maybe selling it for a massive profit but the actual target community got nothing in return.

textDisplay: You are either a liar or ignorant.  Not once did you mention the cost of maintaining a business.  Where did the pizza oven come from?  The refrigerators for the food?  The food itself?  The rent for the business?  The cost of water, electricity, and AC?  The toilet paper for the workers?  Who pays for all that? None of the workers.  The owner pays for that.  Who fixes the equipment when it breaks?  Who buys new equipment? How do they save for those unexpected emergencies when a water line breaks?  If workers always got exactly their worth in labor, the company and the owner would not grow in wealth, that is true, but the business would also cease to function.  You cannot give workers EXACTLY what they are worth.  Even if the workers owned the means of production, they would still have to be paid less than what they are “worth”, because they would all need to pitch in to cover all these expenses.  Also, some jobs require more training than others.  You don’t want a plumber as your surgeon.  Medical school takes time, energy, sacrifice, and intelligence.  That deserves to be rewarded, just as any worker ought to be.  Not all labor is of equal value.  In a hospital, we don’t need 50 guitar players.  Likewise, managing a business and making wise decisions that protect the ability of the business to continue and the employees to accrue wealth is of more value than the person flipping the burgers.  That person can be replaced more easily.  It is harder to find a wise steward with savvy decision-making skills.  Restaurant workers are not the cream of the crop when it comes to intelligence.  Life is not fair.  The IQ distribution is a bell curve, not a column.  Not all people are equal in their worth to a business.  They are equal in their innate value as far as being cared for and loved, but they don’t all deserve to be paid the same.

textDisplay:
Let me explain why this video is bullshit


1. Family Money


You give the examples of billionaires without ever stating what % of billionaires got their start from family. Even if it was, it is hardly an issue because that is not how business success works.
You use the assumption that initial start-up capital provides much of the variance for the reason why they are successful or become billionaires. We know that is bullshit because less than 0.1% of startups become billion dollar ones meaning that 99.9% will not despite funding. Those who don’t make the billionaire club as a business do have better odds but still grim as the failure rate after five years is over 50% and over 70% after the ten-year mark.


2. Exploitative labor BS part 1


The aim is to make it at a less cost than your competitors so a price for that labor is set. When a company goes into another country for labor, they are paying at that labor market rate not home market rate. That is not exploitative, if you were building a home in the Caribbean that cost $150,000 there why would you pay the builders there $800,000 because that is what it would be cost building it in the US? Furthermore, you’re your restaurant example, capitalism brings choice through competition, you don’t have to work at that restaurant, there is no gun to your head.


What is sinister that we teach people they have no choice, you do, and the market will follow the choices of the customers. In Canada, I only buy books from Indigo not from Amazon because I support local. Lastly, you bring up the nonsense of sweat shops without any data, how many billionaires use sweat shops and if so, how long enough to rake in billions to get billionaire status? When the very few times the problem of sweat shops arises it usually comes from the outsourcing factory protocols not from some billionaire strategy black book. You used Rihanna clothing line as example, she made no money from that, Fenty fashion label after less than two years in production has closed. It was never a hit.

3. Exploitative labor BS part 2


Another reason why the term is Exploitative labor is bullshit because it does not explain the actions of why firms do what they do and will do. For example, when 5g becomes more fully on stream that will set the stage for better AI and robotics that will alone eliminate many jobs. I see many companies take that route when it come available. Is that exploitative? Companies are looking for a cost advantage which is what EVERY human being does whether in buying or creating products to sell, which is to get an outcome with lease amount of resource utilization. Its why Garage sales exist, auction houses, used cars, coupons, dollar stores etc.


4. Government Help


I agree with this but you take it to the extreme. The problem with Government is that they are bureaucrats because they cannot see the whole system so they over extend with policies that makes the system slow, hence, the call for deregulation. Yes, they could be catalyst for innovation in some industries and companies such as Apple, Tesla, Microsoft has benefitted greatly from them, a fact that capitalist tend to ignore. This has been brought up a few times by economist Mariana Mazzucato and in her books. The problem is that you site this as a single factor. For example, who cares that Xerox had the graphical interface? It was Apple that saw the vision of what it could do. They spotted the opportunity and hence made money from it.



Where I agree:

I don't believe anyone is 'self'-made but for different factors. Timing, Team, Location, Network and Funding play a big role from an externalities point and internal view factors such as cognition, resilience and proactive orientation play roles as well and I am sure a bunch of others. I don't buy Jeff Bezos' family contribution of $300,000 matters much because I believe he would have found a way to get the money anyway (proactive orientation).

Lastly what people don't know is that factors such as Timing, Team, Location, Network and Funding improves exponentially as you accumulate more money, they are a powerful self reinforcing loop when started. As a person starts making more money in the millions, he/she can get more knowledge on the market (timing), assemble the best team or consult with experts (team), go to multiple locations where there is talent or cost advantages (Location), have more people similar to them who have similar reaches and knowledge advantages (Network), because they are making money, they have more credibility and more people and banks will work with them at the best rates (funding). These advantages only increase with more money.

textDisplay: One of the many things that makes me very, very mad is when conservatives think we are not giving successful business people any credit when pointing out that they are not, in fact, self-made. People like Elon Musk and Rhianna do work for what have but good decisions and careful planning alone didn't make them so wealthy. Many come from wealthy families, had a string of spectacularly good luck, and are supported structurally by our government. Also, wealth begets wealth. It is much easier to become a billionaire if you are already a millionaire than it is for the average person to become a millionaire. Highlighting the structures and government policies that lead to such concentrations of wealth and recognizing that not everyone could become a billionaire if given the same advantages are not mutually exclusive.

People like Elon Musk and Rhianna do work for what have but good decisions and careful planning alone didn't make them so wealthy. Many come from wealthy families, had a string of spectacularly good luck, and are supported structurally by our government. Also, wealth begets wealth. It is much easier to become a billionaire if you are already a millionaire than it is for the average person to become a millionaire. Highlighting the structures and government policies that lead to such concentrations of wealth and recognizing that not everyone could become a billionaire if given the same advantages are not mutually exclusive.

02:08
"The myth of the self made billionaire tries to trick you into believing that anybody could be just like them"

Well, you could. There is certainly no guarantee. But...You could be...

"They can convince you to act against your own self interest"

This proves that leftists are egoistic.
I am not a billionaire and I don't ever expect to be.
It would be in my (at least short term) self interest to promote a 80% tax on billionaire so that I could get my hand on a few bucks (once the 80% tax is divided by the entire country).
I don't promote 80% tax on the rich because it's imoral. It's not my money. I did nothing to get that money. The billionaire did.

But long term it's actually not even in my interest to tax billionaires harder than everyone else. Even if the billionaire gets very rich he also creates a lot of products and wealth for the entire society. Putting brakes on that is foolish.


Maybe Elon and Bezos are not 100% self made - and I don't really care. So what?
But many rich people are self made. Self made in the sense that they started a company with own or investor money and created a success.

06:33

07:02

Why are you worth more to the company? Because it has tools to make you more effective. It has customers, management and all the infrastructure needed to make your work worth more.

Being an accountant is pretty worthless if you are just by yourself.

textDisplay:
Another aspect people don't talk about much when it comes to "Self-Made" Billionaires, is their reliance on existing public infrastructure.

In the case of Bezos:

The internet was developed by the government, using tax dollars (he no longer pays into). Take away the internet, no Amazon, no profits.

The railway, highway, and airport infrastructure that Bezos utilized to deliver his packages was paid for using tax payer funds...which he no longer contributes to. Take away the transportation network, no profits.

While the argument could be made that these things are publicly available and therefor not advantages, the point is that these things were necessary for the early success and continual growth of Amazon, and yet Amazon no longer contributes to the maintenance of existing infrastructure...while also demanding more infrastructure be built to accommodate the company, at no expense to the company of course.

If Amazon was really such a well-run, fiscally responsible company, it would be able to pay its employees well, pay for any infrastructure it needs maintained or built, and still generate a lot of wealth for its backers and corporate officers. That is what a truly symbiotic relationship between a corporation and society would look like, wins for everybody. Instead, Amazon is a parasite taking and taking and rarely giving. They just get away with it because they can buy off the politicians who are supposed to protect us from such depredations...

textDisplay:
Really to acquire wealth, you need to have either the resources up front, or convince someone to risk their resources in your business venture. Also you have to be willing to take risks to the top. Sometimes that might even mean doing things you're not proud of. Most wealth originated from the purchase of land when the US Government was first founded. In the beginning the government was almost giving away ownership. I believe most dynasties started off as land owners, and they increased it from there. I'm not sure, but I think the Kennedys got their wealth from making and selling moonshine when alcohol was prohibited in US. Keep in the mind, that ultimately the system is at fault. When I say system, I include both capitalism and government intervention of capitalism. Even if you try to remove Jeff Bezos or Elon Musk of their wealth, other rich tycoons will just take their place. In the end,
Bezos and Musk are just players in the system like the rest of us. In the past, americans tried to make the wealthy elite contribute more. It's called the federal income system. The original purpose of the income tax system was to make the rich pay. However, they were able to use their resources and find ways to "amend" the income tax system where everyone has to pay, only the middle class pay far more than the other classes. I'll admit, my statements are probably not 100% accurate. This is info I picked up on over the years.
