textDisplay:
@Second Thought - The pizza shop example of Surplus Value at the 7:45 mark is an egregiously bad example. The $78/hour/employee was not surplus value. No one knows how much the surplus value was because the owner did not publicize his costs. Instead, he personally covered all of the costs of operation for the day (rent, equipment, food ingredients, utilities, etc.) out of his own pocket. He also personally paid all the costs for advertising and promotion to get more customers into the shop for the day so that the employees would have more money.

The $78/hour/employee was the total of all sales revenue and tips that came into the shop that day. Every penny that came into the shop went to the employees.

1. Total that came in $78.00
2. Tips (assuming 15% tip rate) $10.20 (this would have gone to the employees anyway and is not part of the Surplus Value created by labor)
3. Sales Revenue for the pizza shop $67.80 (assuming no sales tax)
4. Net profit range for the shop owner (This is the Surplus Value of labor)
4a - Low Average net profit for a pizza restaurant @ 7% of Sales Revenue - $4.75
4b - High Average profit margin for a pizza restaurant @ 10% of Sales Revenue - $ 6.78
4c - Top end profit margin for a pizza restaurant @16% of Sales Revenue - $10.85

Essentially, by giving the employees 100% of the money that came in to the restaurant that day, he personally paid each of them the equivalent of about $61.00/hour/employee ($67.80 - 6.78) out of his own pocket because he did not receive any of the money and still had to pay all the other operating costs for the day.


The only question regarding Surplus Value of Labor for this one event is whether the normal salary the employees receive is equitable in relation to the range of $4.75 to $6.78 per hour the owner is receiving in Net profits as a result of taking the risks of starting a business. If the salary rates are equitable in relation to the owner's risk, then Surplus Value is not an issue. If the salary rates are not equitable, then an adjustment is appropriate, but it won't be anything near $61.00/hour unless the employees intend to pay for a share of the expenses to operate the restaurant.

A pizza shop is among the easier businesses to set up as an employee owned co-op. So if the employees decide to keep the full Surplus Value for themselves, the way to do that is for them to set up their own pizza shop, don't draw a salary, and take the risks of operating a business.

This example is even more egregiously bad because the pizza shop owner is not a billionaire and in the stories I've read he has never claimed to be self-made. Instead, he repeatedly states that his success is in large part due to his employees, which is why he wanted to give back to them by personally covering the $61/hour/employee in operating costs for that day.
textOriginal:
@Second Thought - The pizza shop example of Surplus Value at the 7:45 mark is an egregiously bad example. The $78/hour/employee was not surplus value. No one knows how much the surplus value was because the owner did not publicize his costs. Instead, he personally covered all of the costs of operation for the day (rent, equipment, food ingredients, utilities, etc.) out of his own pocket. He also personally paid all the costs for advertising and promotion to get more customers into the shop for the day so that the employees would have more money. 

The $78/hour/employee was the total of all sales revenue and tips that came into the shop that day. Every penny that came into the shop went to the employees. 

1. Total that came in $78.00
2. Tips (assuming 15% tip rate) $10.20 (this would have gone to the employees anyway and is not part of the Surplus Value created by labor)
3. Sales Revenue for the pizza shop $67.80 (assuming no sales tax)
4. Net profit range for the shop owner (This is the Surplus Value of labor)
4a - Low Average net profit for a pizza restaurant @ 7% of Sales Revenue - $4.75
4b - High Average profit margin for a pizza restaurant @ 10% of Sales Revenue - $ 6.78
4c - Top end profit margin for a pizza restaurant @16% of Sales Revenue - $10.85

Essentially, by giving the employees 100% of the money that came in to the restaurant that day, he personally paid each of them the equivalent of about $61.00/hour/employee ($67.80 - 6.78) out of his own pocket because he did not receive any of the money and still had to pay all the other operating costs for the day.


The only question regarding Surplus Value of Labor for this one event is whether the normal salary the employees receive is equitable in relation to the range of $4.75 to $6.78 per hour the owner is receiving in Net profits as a result of taking the risks of starting a business. If the salary rates are equitable in relation to the owner's risk, then Surplus Value is not an issue. If the salary rates are not equitable, then an adjustment is appropriate, but it won't be anything near $61.00/hour unless the employees intend to pay for a share of the expenses to operate the restaurant.

A pizza shop is among the easier businesses to set up as an employee owned co-op. So if the employees decide to keep the full Surplus Value for themselves, the way to do that is for them to set up their own pizza shop, don't draw a salary, and take the risks of operating a business.

This example is even more egregiously bad because the pizza shop owner is not a billionaire and in the stories I've read he has never claimed to be self-made. Instead, he repeatedly states that his success is in large part due to his employees, which is why he wanted to give back to them by personally covering the $61/hour/employee in operating costs for that day.

The gospel of Marx can be summed up as; "hate the person who is better off than you."
If it wasn't for billionaires like Bezos you wouldn't be able to sit in your underwear and order cheap electronics online. You would be stuck buying from tiny little stores for much higher cost. In capitalism the poor can and do become rich and the rich can and do become poor. One of these days something could happen to Amazon causing it to crash and it's stock value to crumble and you know what happens to Besos' net worth? It would plummet.

Your stuff is great, I'm glad you're shining a light on these things. But the point about the pizza shop workers making 78$/hour as a measure of stolen surplus is very incorrect.

The text says "all money coming into the store, not just profits" was paid. So the money they got wasn't just the siphoned surplus, it was all revenue. None taken out to pay for the pizza ingredients, building upkeep, marketing, insurance, or anything else. It also ignores the fact if customers knew of the event, they might spend more. The place currently has a job listed at 10$ (well above OH min wage), no idea what pizza shop expenses are like.

If I was to guess though for their pay + 100% profit sharing which would be representative of no siphoned value, I’d be surprised if it was over 20$.

textDisplay:
Much of the world's woes can actually be attributed to the entrepreneurs themselves, as stupidly backwards as that may sound to right-wing types. The very people that provide the ideas for the products and services that we enjoy are to blame because of a large amount of arbitrary laws that were created by them and continue to this day for the purpose of enriching these people and the people that provide funding for them (shareholders) at the expense of everyone else. Real "free markets" actually tend towards the networking of social entrepreneurs who collaborate to provide ideas for products and services that any other entity can actually build upon (and are compensated more modestly), rather than having states use Intellectual Property/Patenting/Copyright to enclose those ideas only to even further enrich private entrepreneurs. The great incentive of "private innovation", at least as it is supposed to exist in the minds of many, doesn't even naturally exist in the real world, especially in modern times, because no company is going to want spend a lot of money on research and development only to have it become a positive externality that competitors use for free.

Also, the state creates oglipolistic banking and land ownership conditions that benefit rich property users at the expense of the general public. They also regulate voluntary credit unions, and all of this makes it harder for enterprises more in line with the natural condition of social entrepreneurship (like say, worker owned cooperatives that engage in mutual aid) to access capital.

Read “The Iron Fist Behind the Invisible Hand” by Kevin Carson

The reality is that Capitalism and the state are one and the same. There's no capitalism without the statist conditions that benefit capitalists at the expense of the public and the mass indoctrination necessary to keep the working class from just simply banding together to work for themselves.

Real "free markets" actually tend towards the networking of social entrepreneurs who collaborate to provide ideas for products and services that any other entity can actually build upon (and are compensated more modestly), rather than having states use Intellectual Property/Patenting/Copyright to enclose those ideas only to even further enrich private entrepreneurs. The great incentive of "private innovation", at least as it is supposed to exist in the minds of many, doesn't even naturally exist in the real world, especially in modern times, because no company is going to want spend a lot of money on research and development only to have it become a positive externality that competitors use for free.

Also, the state creates oglipolistic banking and land ownership conditions that benefit rich property users at the expense of the general public. They also regulate voluntary credit unions, and all of this makes it harder for enterprises more in line with the natural condition of social entrepreneurship (like say, worker owned cooperatives that engage in mutual aid) to access capital.

Read “The Iron Fist Behind the Invisible Hand” by Kevin Carson

The reality is that Capitalism and the state are one and the same. There's no capitalism without the statist conditions that benefit capitalists at the expense of the public and the mass indoctrination necessary to keep the working class from just simply banding together to work for themselves.

textDisplay:
Once had a guy who argued with me when I said Capitalisms wet dream is legalized slavery. He said that Capitalism does the exact opposite that it actively abolishes slavery and used the U.S. as an example... I then pointed out to him how the Civil War was fought over slavery but the reason behind keeping slavery was intact was because it the potential cost of the labor needed without slavery was going to massively hurt or put people out of business. I also pointed to the manufacturing in the U.S. over the last 70 years has been declining because labor is too expensive, how it was shipped overseas to save money... all the while the same companies that shipped labor overseas increased the price of their goods as well providing a massive increase in profits.

Long story short he said he was never going to convince me, a dirty socialist, that Capitalism is the only option for long term success. Ironically he called me that after I had pointed out that I like Capitalism, that it has provided great prosperity for Americans before, but that during that time of great prosperity there were socialist regulations placed to protect the people from the predatory businesses of a capitalist economic system.

11:12 well that would be a world without any growth, investment or innovation. Companies need surplus to grow, adapt to changing market environment or to simply survive some difficulties. If that Pizza shop owner did that every day, where he would get the money to buy a new more energy efficient pizza oven or to start a new location? Where would he get the money to keep his business afloat when a busted pipe render it inoperable for weeks?
For bigger companies it's all about having money to keep R&D going, buying start-ups to get new technologies and branching into other markets. Look at Amazon, it is no longer just selling books on internet, it branched into cloud computing, video streaming and even making and selling their own electronic devices. You need surplus to do that, if you are giving all back to your employees there is nothing left to spend on improving the company.

textDisplay: I seriously agree with a lot that you put out with this channel. There is, though, one part in this video I disagree with. Mostly the "earning the full value of your work" and the $78 an hour statistic from the pizza joint. Simply put, profit has to happen. I would LOVE to earn what I put out in the kitchen, but if the business doesn't pull in overhead then the business won't stand. I think a more accurate way to analyze the situation would be to understand that most businesses take advantage of this amount and what should be balanced is the amount of profit put towards the wages of the employees. That the extra profit gets put back into the company instead of being funneled to the fat cat on top who already is making more money than God. But even still, there has to be amount of overhead that will keep the company running and the employees employed.

textDisplay:
Self-made is a spectrum, not a binary. $300.000 is NOT an "absurd head start" to launch an online shipping company, what fucking weed are you smoking? Do you know how tiny a sum 300k is for launching a worldwide business? Let me remind you that Bezos turnd those 300k into almost 2 TRILLION dollars. Also, those $300k was his parent's only life savings, not a cash injection they had lying around. There's a reason Bezos worked at McDonald's as a teen. Turning $300.000 into almost 2 TRILLION dollars is not some everyday feat, and acting like a few hundred thousand dollars sets you up for a certain path of success is ridiculous, which is what you are essentially implying.

The exact details of to what extent Elon's dad's wealth helped his later success are a bit flimsy and uncertain. From what we know, Elon and his dad were constantly clashing, and Elon did not get any investment or sum of wealth from his dad, he paid for his college degree with student loans. So while growing up with rich parents definitely doesn't hurt, it is a tenuous argument to say that this was in any way a significant factor in his current wealth. Having decently rich parents can you plenty of opportunities, but it in no way gives you anywhere near the ability to become a tech multibillionaire by itself. Elon is no rags to riches story, but you can make a pretty good argument that he fits on the self-made spectrum.

This video is extremely superficial and reeks of someone who does the most bare-bones research possible to support his own worldview and agenda, and then just rolls with that like it's the whole story. Is it so hard to introduce some nuance into these topics? You present the world in an incredibly naive, black-and-white, good-and-evil worldview.

Like I said: Self-made is a spectrum, not a binary.

Power lines didn't run to rural communities until federal government mandated it.  The power lines are not profitable until the government mandates the fees to all consumers to pay for the power line going to a few people in rural communities.

textDisplay:
I can think of 1 self made billionaire in the history of humanity. Markus Persson, the creator of Minecraft. While I haven't been following anything he said in the last few years, back when he still owned Mojang he knew damn well how lucky he was to even become a billionaire. And even in his case, it's up for debate how much of a self made billionaire he actually is. After all, it's not like Mojang was a workers coop. So the most he can realistically claim is that he is a self made multimillionaire.

Even if he can indeed be considered a self made billionaire, that is 1 person. 1 person in the entire history of humanity. 1 out of 7+ billion people alive today and every single person who died since the invention of capitalism. So easily a 1 in 20 billion chance at best if I'm very generous with my numbers.

textDisplay:
Until class thinking awakens in people, any conversation is useless. capitalism cannot exist for a long time, its main goal is to increase its resources for the subsequent transition to a higher economic formation. Towards fascism or communism. If there is no transition, a recession ensues and an overproduction crisis begins.
When the USSR died, communism in the world also died. China is a capitalist state in which people are exploited in the same way. The only way to change anything is to revive the world international. This is the only way to change anything.
But the capitalists will not just give up their power. Sooner or later, the number of contradictions will become so great that it will be impossible to continue living. And then it will be scrapped. Cruel bloody, scrapped. Because people driven to despair will be ready for anything.

textDisplay:
Elon's dad didn't give him a single penny. In fact, he ditched the whole family when he was a kid. Once again, thanks to your dogmatic following of "billionaire bad", you distort reality to fit your narrative, just like the right does. Shame on you, I'm disappointed and I expected more of you.
Digging even deeper into our this distorted narrative, the loans the government gave him for Tesla got fully repaid. The tax breaks his company get are for crucial technologies that move humankind forward and they repay themselves to the taxpayer many times over - unlike the much more massive fossil fuel company subsidies. In fact, if anyone can be even mildly close to be called deserving of his wealth (although I think this level of wealth inequality is unacceptable, regardless of merit) - that's him. After all, he's the chief engineer at his companies and he actually puts in the 80-hour work weeks a leader should.
And yes, the workers in his companies aren't unionized, which is definitely not good. And yes, I'm sure the working conditions (although by far not comparable to Amazon's) could be better and the pay - more equitable. But I think that all of this just adds to my point - you're picking on him just because he's the 2nd richest person on the planet, while there are much less richer billionaires and multi-millionaires who lead exorbitant and wasteful lives, hoarding money for themselves, rather than putting them where their mouths are like Elon does.
The worst part is that as always, you are absolutely right about everything in your video. It's a real shame to me you always tend to put a spoon of shit in your barrel of honey like this. When will people learn to look past their dogmatic beliefs? You even show that you're capable of that - you clearly ignore the part of Marx's work that is explicitly antisemitic and violent, while focusing on the good. Why can't you do the same for non-socialists?

The worst part is that as always, you are absolutely right about everything in your video. It's a real shame to me you always tend to put a spoon of shit in your barrel of honey like this. textDisplay: It's it just me, or are his points lacking some nuance. Such as, how there's an inertia to the systems and structures these individuals climbed through that no individual could change. And that though the direction and motivation for this system's momentum is unfair to the masses, it is reflective of our nature as humans; mirroring the same flaws we, maybe not as individuals, but certainly as  a species have always struggled with since time immemorial. And though Marxism's approach to wealth and recourse distribution is fairer in it's inceptive stage, it too devolves and degrades into a similar pattern of power concentration and oligarchal tyranny for much the same reasons as capitalism. And though one system seems to have a more reasonable and or tolerable floor than the other, I do believe that both systems are viable and can function for the greater good of the masses if properly structured and regulated. However, perfect though the design and implementation of either system may be, once humans enter the equation, perfection exits it, and on a long enough timeline a measure of inequalities and unfairness will arise, which will self reinforce and magnify. I don't know if there's an easy solution to this prisoner's dilemma of human nature, or if a hypothetical neutral party such as artificial intelligences of the future can square this circle, but what I do know is, vilifying billionaires as a class is counterintuitive so far as, all things being equal many of us would follow very similar patterns of behavior given that we'd be under the same game theoretic pressures and that we too are human, just like them.

And though Marxism's approach to wealth and recourse distribution is fairer in it's inceptive stage, it too devolves and degrades into a similar pattern of power concentration and oligarchal tyranny for much the same reasons as capitalism. And though one system seems to have a more reasonable and or tolerable floor than the other, I do believe that both systems are viable and can function for the greater good of the masses if properly structured and regulated. However, perfect though the design and implementation of either system may be, once humans enter the equation, perfection exits it, and on a long enough timeline a measure of inequalities and unfairness will arise, which will self reinforce and magnify. I don't know if there's an easy solution to this prisoner's dilemma of human nature, or if a hypothetical neutral party such as artificial intelligences of the future can square this circle, but what I do know is, vilifying billionaires as a class is counterintuitive so far as, all things being equal many of us would follow very similar patterns of behavior given that we'd be under the same game theoretic pressures and that we too are human, just like them.

textDisplay: The most important part of today's ''Innovation'' is all about selling an idea to a venture capital firm to get the starting funding. No matter how stupid the idea is, as long as it can keep the chain of value turning, then congratulations, mission accomplished. Just sell the startup to a monopoly capital group, they will use their already dominant status in the market to ''disrupt'' it. All these are not revolved around how the product/service can improve people's life. Instead, it's all about letting the money flow. The faster it flows and the more surplus it extracts the better. Billionaires are just a byproduct of this insanity of capital accumulation. Taxing them alone won't fix it. The only way out are breaking the chain of value and ending the exploitation by the public ownership of all knowledge and means of production.

textDisplay: To undermine Jeff Bezos' current Amazon, with a "absurd head-start $300,000.00" is laughable. Most small farms have greater than 300k in equipment - that is not an absurd amount of starting capital. Both Bezos and Musks stories are well reported.  Regarding race/gender - there are more Chinese/Indians on earth than white men, why are they not more numerous billionaires? Regarding exploitation - some people dont make positive value, and are still paid. Regarding Gov help - most public research/grants are 10's Millions, where these project (rockets/Pharma) require 100's Millions. There are some gouging examples (see insulin), but it is not the standard. Also, this wealth doesnt go "directly to the CEOs", that is incredibly disingenuous and betrays the millions of shareholders. Any pension, retirement plan, or 401(k) holder is in the market, and broadly benefit; not to mention local tax engines, jobs, or people who need life saving medicines (see orphan drugs)

textDisplay:
I'm a conservative and I find your videos interesting. I thought it'd be interesting to do a point-by-point critical analysis from a generally opposing view. I'm writing this as I watch your video.

Opening: I think it's true that not anyone can become a billionaire, and it's not as simple as it seems. Things often outside your control have to align just perfectly. I pretty much agree with you here.


The taxes thing has virtually nothing to do with the thesis of the video. Afterthought: You said you'd come back to it later but it was hardly mentioned, and when it was... well you'll see my thoughts below.

4:26 Hard work doesn't hurt. However, it alone is obviously not enough. I'm intrigued to see if you explore this later in the video.

5:16 You are now attacking these people claiming they have lied, but the only words we have to go off of are yours. So far you have not made a single quote, and are accusing them of lying. I can't get behind that.

5:37 "Billionaires never get there alone" I could not agree more. Their parents definitely played a huge role both in raising them and with well-executed financial support. Here I see the point your making that "self-made billionaires" is a misleading title.

6:25 Here you bring up an interesting point. White males definitely are the majority of US billionaires. This makes sense as when you're talking about such large sums of money it's not unfair to assume biased financial decisions from centuries ago are in play. It will take time for society to fully heal. This is not new information. However, this does not make these billionaires any less self-made necessarily. If it was a black billionaire who came from a wealthy family I doubt you or many others would be making the same accusation of privilege, though it is by definition so. While on the topic I looked into data on the racial wealth gap. It is indeed healing, though most news networks would like you to believe otherwise. Most graphs off of a quick Google show somewhat opposite information than what the Federal Reserve reports here: https://www.federalreserve.gov/econres/notes/feds-notes/disparities-in-wealth-by-race-and-ethnicity-in-the-2019-survey-of-consumer-finances-20200928.htm

6:34 Quick note, exploitation is in my opinion the biggest problem with any free market. I think it's pretty likely we'll agree here.

7:48 Jumped from a legitimate mathematic explanation of why you can't be paid all the value someone produces to calling it stealing. It's literally impossible for a business to be profitable to anyone without surplus at least in part going to the owners and the business. I'm picking up a theme in this video that's ignoring the fact that starting a business IS hard work, even if it's a lot more relaxed keeping it running once it's done. This is hardly stealing unless it becomes unfair. Even then it's not technically stealing, it's just an unfair deal.

8:35 Totally agree here. Unfair working conditions and poor compensation are bad things.

8:41 "...often children" HOLD UP, are we talking about China? That ain't the US pal, child labor has been illegal for a LONG time. Dang it, you made me use caps. Anyway if you're going to be making accusations like that please have some specific sources cited IN the video. That's pretty serious stuff. Not to mention I'm pretty sure that the stock footage you used came from a third-world country where conditions aren't comparable.

9:20 I think I'm being called a hypocrite. Maybe other conservatives disagree, but I don't think the government should assist any company unless it directly benefits something on the government's agenda like any other use of tax dollars. Example: I don't think the government funding Amazon is ethical, but I do think the government paying a road company to make public roads is ethical. Billionaires might disagree. I don't know I didn't see any quotations.

9:52 Just stated that Elon Musk's companies would have no hope of existing without such massive tax breaks. Perhaps this is true, however, the problem is that you said this to warrant the point that he needed the government. Essentially you claimed the following: Because the government lifted the government's taxes Elon Musk required the government to be successful. This is like unto: Steve chose not to hit Sally so Sally should be grateful to Steve. Literally, the same logic is used by awful people who prey on others. The amount of hypocrisy here is disturbing, to say the least.

11:19 I'm liking your conclusion so far for the most part. Something I did fail to mention earlier is that the $78/hour wage for pizza workers is likely very misleading. Not every pizza shop makes that much, and you can't forego the excess to the workers every time or you get behind on maintenance, and the owner himself starves. Higher wages are certainly possible though, just not always that high.

Final thoughts: Pretty good video, some valid points, and a great thesis and conclusion. But also some radical and uncalled-for accusations were made in the middle without presenting evidence. Looking at the sources you did cite in the description, they are mostly known to be left-leaning. Also while looking through I did not find a single primary source, though it's possible I missed some. The vast majority if not all are secondary sources meaning they all have been affected by multiple levels of opinion; likely ones that align with your opinion. Usually not a big deal but again, you made some serious accusations in this video against real people with real lives. It's at least worth presenting first-hand evidence.

But hey, leaving on a positive note: I really did enjoy the video and I like your channel. I might even be able to support you on Patreon if you were to use better sources and were more clear about them in your videos. I'll probably join the Discord if I'm welcome. It never hurts to have someone with another viewpoint around.

textDisplay: The Ohio Pizza example is a little disingenuous, no money saved for rent or future ingredients or maintenance or anything else. Restaurants have to operate on razor thin margins as it is. That and they relied on a boost in sales over the cause and had people tipping $100. That's not something to build a cause on. However, it kinda proves the point. Workers and small business's shouldn't have to rely on donations and charity to be able to live comfortably. And maybe if the biggest employeers and exploiters paid a proper wage, that increased buying power would trickle out and more people would be able to spend money at the local pizza place regularly.

textDisplay: Great video, but just wanted to clarify that the pizza workers were receiving "all money coming into the store", aka gross income, which includes money that would have been spent on operating costs. It's net income, not gross, that is the surplus value. So if the pizza workers were being paid the full value of their labor, it would be significantly less than $78/hr, but would obviously be much more than what they are currently making, assuming that the pizzeria turns a profit.
textOriginal: Great video, but just wanted to clarify that the pizza workers were receiving "all money coming into the store", aka gross income, which includes money that would have been spent on operating costs. It's net income, not gross, that is the surplus value. So if the pizza workers were being paid the full value of their labor, it would be significantly less than $78/hr, but would obviously be much more than what they are currently making, assuming that the pizzeria turns a profit.
